cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are expected to leave Port Said on or about the following dates:--
Port-Said to London via Brindisi
The BRINDISI steamer leaves PORT-SAID after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from PORT-SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI or via MARSEILLES £25.9.11
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave SUEZ for ADEN and BOMBAY every Wednesday, and for AUSTRALIA and CHINA every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for CALCUTTA, fortnightly, and another for JAPAN. Passengers can embark at PORT-SAID.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. Thos, Cook & Son (Egypt) Ltd.… … … … … … … … CAIRO.
George Royle, Esq… … … … … … … … … … … … … … PORT-SAID.
Messrs. Haselden & Co. … … … … … … … … … … … … ALEXANDRIA.
F.G. DAVIDSON, Superintendant P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt. SUEZ. 81-12-90

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying the full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of one-third of their fare back if the return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or an abatement of 20% if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thosmas Cook & Son. Alexandria : —B. J. Moss & Co.—For all information apply to

S.S. Yorkshire 4,196 tons, will leave Suez about November 23.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,635 tons, will leave Port-Said about November 14.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons will leave Port-Said leaves about November 29.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Belgrade, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, calling as required at TOR
(for Mount Sinai) and YAMBO, and continuing in alternate weeks to SUAKIM, MASSOWAH,HODEIDAH, and ADEN.
N.B. Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

REMARKS.-Surgeons and Stewardesses carried. Ice rooms, Punkaha, and every comfort for a tropical climate. Passengers and Cargo booked through to Continental and American Ports and to all important Ports on Coast of India, Persian Gulf, East Africa, Burmah, Straits Settlements, Eastern Archipelago, Java and Queensland Ports. Rates of Passage money, as below, include table for First and Second Class Passengers only but not wines or spirits, which may be had on board for payment. Passengers are allowed to break the voyage – any Intermediate Ports and proceed by following steamer in which there may be accommodation.
First Class Fares from Suez to
From Port-Said £2 less Homeward, and £2 more Outward. Second class, two thirds of 1st Class Fares.

div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 9th and 28rd November.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited,
undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.p: Millions of bottles of Bovril are used annually-- used in the sick-room where Bovril is the nurse's 'second self' -- used in the kithchen where Bovril is the cook's 'right hand;-- used on all occasions where strength and sustenance are required. Bovril as a food has received the endorsement of some of the greatest scientists of the age.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.

From 8 a.m. up to noon of yesterday the weather remained boisterous, very squally, with frequent heavy showers from the N.W. and a rough sea. It gradually abated and gave place to a light breeze and smoother sea, which continued throughout the night. Barometer still keeping steady.
At 7a.m. to-day a heavy shower passed over Abdul Abbas district, but none over the Kom-el-Nadoura Observatory.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
OBSERVATIONS BY SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
For the 24 hours ending 8 a.m. Yesterday

div.p: THE PLANETS,
Mercury is too near the Sun in the early part of the month to be visible, becoming an evening star later.
Venus is an evening star setting about two hours after the Sun.
Mars rises about 2.30 a.m. and shines as a morning star. Jupiter is to be seen in the South about 10 p.m. and sets. about 4 p.m.
Saturn souths about 7 p.m. and sets at midnight.
The chief constellations in the south at 9 p.m. are Andromeda and Pegasus near the zenith, Cetus about 50 deg, and Sculptor about 30 deg. above the horizon.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager - -.R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
THUURSDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1904.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: According to a telegram from London to day, the negotiations between Great Britain and Russia in regard to what has been de- scribed by Lord Rosebery as the "unspeakable outrage" of the Russian Baltic Fleet, are pro- gressing. The commission which is to study the matter will probably consist of an admital and a legal adviser on both sides, together with naval officers belonging to neutrals. Great Britain is in favour of Paris, and Russia of The Hague, as the place for the meeting. Other essential points require the most careful consi- deration. Meanwhile, we are told, the Russian fleet will probably be thousands of miles away before the enquiry even begins. This does not

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: perspiration and dust, so disagreeable, yet so common in hot weather, can easily be removed by using Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap, A pleasantly perfumed pure antiseptic soap which can be used for all toilet purposes and as a preventive of contagion. It contains 10% Crystal Carbolic, and so has a healthy action on the skin and assists to improve the complexion.
Calvert's Carbolic Ointment
contains pure Carbolic Acid (healing and antiseptic) and other useful ingredients to cure or alleviate sunburn, chafed skin, piles, cuts, burns, insect bites, &c.
F.C. CALVERT & Co., Manchester, England.

sound satisfactory, but we have sufficient confidence in the Government to believe that every guarantee has been received that the fleet will no longer constitute a menace to our shipping. We are content to await the results of the enquiry with calm and dignified patience. The attitude of England has, indeed, throughout been characterised with admirable calmness. The outrage touched us vitally. The offence was not only one against the lives of English. men, it was an outrage committed on the high seas against the nation which claims to rule the waves. Nothing could so stir the country as an atrocity which touches a maritime people in so sensitive a spot, and nothing could seem more dastardly to English ideas than a coward- ly attack, whether deliberate or unpremeditated, upon unarmed and defenceless men. Had the fishermen been French, or of any other nationality, our indignation would scarcely have been less, though our personal honour would not have been involved. The measure of our anger's depth, and the measure of our de-1 termination, may be taken by the calmness we continue to display. It is a dangerous calm, symptomatic of feelings that are too deep and sacred for words or demonstration. It is earnestly to be hoped that it is properly understood abroad, and especially at St. Petersburg. For any misapprehension which confuses patience with pusillanimity, or moderation with readiness to allow this outrage to be passed over as other outrages, almost as "unspeakable," have been, will as surely lead to disaster as that obstirate defiance by Russia of which perturbing signals have not been lacking. There. is no shred of division or irresolution in Great and Greater Britain. Never before has the country been so absolutely one. If quarrel we must have we have that quarrel just, and once in we will so bear ourselves that others may beware of us. Our conscience acquits us of bellicose or Chauvinistic impatience. We have borne ourselves like men in our treatment of an unparalleled situation. We still earnestly hope that our moderation and dignity will be rewarded as they deserve. But if it fall out otherwise, we shall bear ourselves like men to the bitter end, strong in the justice of our cause

div.head: THE WAR.
div.p: The only war news we have to-day is contained in a telegram from Tokio reporting a tremendous bombardment of Port Arthur, the fall of which is said to be near at hand. Meantime, all is quiet in Manchuria, though we may hear at any time that the Japanese have resumed the offensive. The annals of scientific warfare would be vainly searched for any tactical position re- sembling that of the two vast armies now facing one another between Liao-yang and Mukden. For fully two weeks, each of these immense forces has virtually stood at bay, challenging the other to come on. Pretty equally matched in numbers and pugnacity, they only wait for an order to rush at the foe, and obedience will be rendered with all possible alacrity. But Marshal Oyama and General Kuropatkin are concerned with matters of higher moment from their respective standpoints. It was the Russian late effort to march south, to relieve Port Arthur, which influenced the Japanese commander to replace offensive strategy by defensive. Similarly, it was the Japanese impetuous northerly advance that constrained Kuropatkin, after the failure of his attempt to get south, to halt on the Sha-ho. In the one case, the object is the capture of Port Arthur by starvation and storm combined before relief arrives; in the other, the Russians feel them- selves bound to retain possession of Mukden. at any cost. In effect, it is a game of patience, and it only remains to be seen which side will be the first to give way to irritation at the delay

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive inspected his estates yesterday at Mariout, and returned in the evening to .Montazah palace, where he is spending today. The Gonvernorat of Cairo has issued invitations to numerous officials and notables to present themselves at the station at 11.30 a.m. next Tuesday to greet hisHighness on his arrival. The Ministry of War has given orders for a detachment to be' present as a guard of () The train in which his Highness travels will stop at Damanhour, Tantah, (Buket el) San, and Benha.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL.
div.p: Largest 1 class and most comfortable hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Central position. Under English management. 81.11.94

div.head: BECK &amp CO'S PILSENER BEER
div.p: BREMEN.
FEARS NO HONEST COMPETITION FOR QUALITY.
N.B.—Inferior Brande now being offered to Manager of certain good cercles.
Beware of evilly disposed competitors running down this very Superior Brand of Beer.

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL,
div.p: CAIRO.
Open all the year round.
ELECTRIC LIGHT, —LIFT, —MODERATE CHARGES
RAMADAN begins on Tuesday next.
THE SLEENAN BASE is to be heard at Alexandria by Judge Saumarez on the 10th inst.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.-
div.p: The next meeting of the Legislative Council is not expected to take place before December 1.

div.head: AMERICAN MISSION.-
div.p: The English services in Tantah under the auspices of the American Mission will be resumed next Sabbath, 6th inst., at 11 a.m., and will be held as formerly once every two weeks.

div.head: SHOOTING OUTRAGE.
div.p: The director of the sugar factory at Bibeh has been fired at and slightly wounded while standing by his window in the evening. A dissatisfied or dismissed workman is believed to have been guilty of the crime.

div.head: NEW LINER.
div.p: Another new steamer (called the Braco, a sister ship to the Milo) for the Bell's Asia Minor S.S. Company, arrived at Alexandria from Hull and the Syrian Coast yesterday. She is commanded by Capt. J. McLaren, this being the second steamer which he has brought out from home.

div.head: PROFITABLE PASTIME.-
div.p: It is not only the wish to learn quickly which urges so many to go to the Berlitz Schools, but also the prospect of taking an hour's lesson in the most agreeable way. For example, many ladies take lessons simply for pleasure a very useful pastime. A trial lesson in English, French, or any other language may be had at Alexandria, 26, Rue Eglise Copte, or at Cairo, 1, Sharia Kamel. [ADVT.]

div.head: THE PYRAMIDS.-
div.p: Visitors to the Pyramids will be pleased to learn that an attempt is being made to meet the requirements of the "inner man" in this locality. A bar and restaurant have been opened where tea, etc., can be obtained at moderate prices. All the refreshments are supplied by Mr. Spathis, the well-known merchant and mineral water manufacturer, and this is a sufficient guarantee of their high quality.

THE NEW NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD'Imperial Mail steamer Prinz Eitel Friedrich, a description of which we, gave in a recent issue, left Suez yesterday morning, bound to China. She had a full first and second-class passenger list, which included 17 naval officers, 32 cadets, and 10 non-commissioned officers, reliefs for the German squadron in the Far East. There were also on board 17 Belgian soldiers in charge of an officer, bound for China.

H.M. TRANSPORT Soudan (Capt. S. de B. Lockyer, R.N.R.) arrived at Port Said on Tuesday from Bombay for Malta and Southampton. There were 1,362 of all ranks on board, including the Cheshire Regiment, numbering 427 officers and men, who are to be stationed at Lichfield on their arrival in England. Sixty-nine details are to land at Malta. The officer commanding the troops is Lt. Col. Hardy, Cheshire Regt.

div.head: COQUELIN AINE.
div.p: Coquelin Ainé makes his debut at the Zizinia Theatre tomorrow evening in Molière's comedy Tartufe, in which he will play the title role. It will be interesting if we give a few particulars of the great French actor's life. Coquelin Ainé is the son of a baker, and was destined originally to follow that trade. but evincing a great aptitude for the stage, he went to Paris and was admitted to the Conservatoire on December 29, 1859, joining M. Regnier's class, of which he became the most brilliant pupil. He obtained the second prize for comedy, and made his debut at the Théâtre Français on December 7, 1860, in the character of Gros-René in the "Dépit Amoureux." He afterwards played with success in the "Fourberies de Scapin," "Mariage de Figaro," "Don Juan," and other classical pieces; Lupin in "La Mère Confidente; the Marquis in "Le Joueur;" Annibal in "L'Aventurière," He created the role of Anatole in "Une Loge d'Opera," John in "Trop Curieux," Gagneux in "Jean Baudry," Vincent in "L'Eillet Blanc," Aristide in "Le Lion Amoureux," Gringoire in the play of that name, Beaubourg in "Paul Forestier," Eucrate in "Le Coq de Mycille," M. Coquelin has obtained great success in society by reciting in private and at public meetings, and has thus added to the reputation of new poets, particularly of Eugène Manuel and François Coppée. In 1886 he was put on the list of "societaires pensionnaires" of the Theatre Français, and this prevented him from appearing as an actor in any French theatre. But, after travelling abroad in America and Alsace at the head of a dramatic company of his own formation, he re-entered the Comedie Française in December, 1889, and played Mascarille, Diafoirus, and Argente, and other parts, in order to support his son Jean, at that time making his first appearances as an actor. He created the part of Labussière in M. Sardou's "Thermidor," which after three representations was interdicted by the French Government His next creation was (January 25, 1891). Petruccio in a modified version of the "Taming of the Shrew" (Nov. 1892). As his engagement at the Theatre Français lasts only six months each year, he has recently taken to touring abroad with a company of his own selection, and in the summer of 1892 he brought "Thermi- dor" and "La Megère Apprivoisée" to London. He is the author of several works on the comedian's art.

div.head: THE KOM OMBO CO.
div.p: A GREAT UNDERTAKING.

We have been favoured with some interest- ing details regarding the progress being made by the Kom Ombo Company, which is engaged in undertaking the development of the great plain extending from the Nile to Giebel Silsileh. The undertaking is financed by Sir Ernest. Cassel and Messrs. Suares and Cattaui. The concession extends to 120,000 feddans, with the option of taking up another 40,000 feddans at a slightly higher level, which is now about to be surveyed.
A correspondent, writing on the subject, says:

The work which is now being done at Kom Ombo is one of the most important under- takings which has ever been attempted in this country. The Suez Canal and the Assouan Dam may take precedence of it, but, for my part, I have no objection to stating that the work now being taken in hand at Kom Ombo is fully entitled to take the third place. Nobody, who has not visited and personally inspected the works, can have the slightest conception of their magnitude and of the enormous task, which has been undertaken in order to make this huge desert plain a smiling area of cultivated land. It is a great pity that the disaster of last year, when the pumping building tumbled down, should have greatly impeded the work. At present the pamping installation is being rapidly developed. The levelling of the land, the making of canals, the laying of the piping, and the many other odd jobs, necessitated by such a gigantic undertaking, are being rapidly brought to completion to enable crops to be grown at an early date. No less than four thousand men are now engaged on the work. One of the most remarkable portions of the work is the pumping installation. Vast shops have been erected for the pumps and all the other kinds of mechanical works. Birch Bey is the great organiser and manager of this property. From the conversation which I had with him, he appeared to be quite satisfied with the progress that is being made and he stated that he had no doubt but that Sir Ernest Cassel would be equally satisfied.

div.head: MENZALEH CANAL & NAVIGATION CO.
div.p: The powerful new dredger for the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Company has now been built, and it is expected that it will be at work in about a week's time. The order for the fleet of this company has been placed in the hands of the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company, who are charged with the whole of the order. The fleet will consist of six barges, two passenger steamers, and two tugs, and all these vessels will be built in England. They will be delivered by June 1, 1905. By that date it is hoped to open a portion of the canal (30 kilomètres) between Matarieh and Port Said. This will be a great advantage for pas- sengers. The Belgian company which has a light railway in this part of the Delta will run a service of specially quick trains from Mansourah to Matarieh in connection with the boats of the Menzaleh Company. The time occupied on the journey from Matarieh to Port Said will thus be shortened to five hours.
The immense possibilities for the develop- ment of the Sharkieh Province owing to this rapid communication are obvious.

div.head: PORT SAID DEVELOPMENT.
div.p: NEW HARBOUR WORKS.

At the end of last year the Suez Canal Company invited tenders for making two new basins on the Asiatic side of Port Said harbour, one of which was to accommodate the colliers that discharge there and, the other the petro- leum tank steamers.

Among the numerous tenders received from all parts of Europe, that sent in by the Société de Grands Travaux de Marseille was accepted. Including the additional or supplementary works that the Canal Company will carry out itself, the total cost of constructing these two new basins will amount to about three million franes, or £120,000. Once these basins are completed, that now known as the "Bassin Abbas," near the waterworks, on the African side, will be utilized for steamers generally, other than the colliers which at present use it exclusively.

The Suez Canal Company intends likewise to considerably imprové the two other basins, known by the names of the Bassin de l'Arsenal and the Bassin Chérif, on the same side of the shore, by enlarging and deepening them and adapting or making them available also for cargo steamers of the largest tonnage and draught. As a result of these improvements and changes the general workshops will have to be removed elsewhere. They will, at the same time, be much enlarged, remodelled, and improved. After a long study of this question the chief engineer of the company, now in Paris, recommended that the new buildings should be erected on the Asiatic side of the harbour, opposite the town, where sufficient space is available, and at this moment a definite project is before the directors for their approval.

On the other hand, a short time back the Canal Company imported three large porteurs, floating receivers or mud tanks, which are used, in connection with the powerful marine dredgers in the port. To increase the dredging operations necessary to keep the port at a uniform and requisite depth, the company has ordered another steamer dredger and mud tank combined, of the type known as the Puissante. Of the new floating dock recently arrived at Port Said from England we have already given & description,

div.head: MURDER IN A THEATRE.
div.p: A DASTARDLY OUTRAGE.
The Eden Music-hall at Alexandria, where the recent fire panic took place, was the scene last night of a dastardly outrage.

About 10.30 p.m., whilst the performance was going on, the ticket-collector was seen to t rush into the auditorium closely pursued by the man in charge of the box-office, of Greek nationality, who carried a dagger in his hand. The latter fell upon his victim and inflicted a deep wound in the back, from which the man fell in front of the stage. He attempted to rise and escape, but was furiously attacked twice and fell dying at the side entrance of the i theatre, leaving a trail of blood behind him. The audience, panic-striken, rushed to the exits of the theatre, and it was left to the fireman on duty to effect the capture of the murderer. The latter seized his belt axe and felled the man to the ground near his dying victim. The murderer, however, escaped the clutches of the fireman and was finally arrested as he emerged into the open street by the ghaffir on duty on a sign from the fireman, who blew his whistle.
The man so brutally attacked, who is an Italian, was removed to the Greek Hospital, but expired on the way. His assassin has been incarcerated at Labbane caracol pending his trial.
The motive of the crime has not as yet transpired, but it evidently arose from a violent quarrel which the two men had at the entrance of the theatre.
ARRESTED FOR "SCORCHING."

The curious experience of having before him as defendant a member of a reigning house (says the Globe) has befallen the district ma- gistrate of the French Commune of Tartas. A tourist had been stopped on the highway for driving a motor car at excessive speed, and on being brought before the magistrate proved to be Prince Mohamed Ibrahim of Egypt. A small fine was inflicted.
COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
The next meeting of the Council of Ministers has been put off till after the arrival of H.H. the Khedive in Cairo.

div.head: VISIT OF GREEK FLEET.
div.p: The members of the Khedivial Yacht Club will be "at home" to the officers of the Greek Fleet at the club-house on Wednesday next from 3 to 6 p.m., when special races will be held.

div.head: KING'S BIRTHDAY.
div.p: (NOVEMBER 9.)
There will be the usual official reception at the Consulate during the forenoon. In the afternoon the Consul-General and Mrs. Gould will be "at home" from 3.30 to 6.30.

div.head: PLAGUE AT SMYRNA.
div.p: In consequence of two suspicious cases of plague having been discovered at Smyrna on the 29th ulto, arrivals at Constantinople from that port are subject to a medical examination.

div.head: NEW BOOK ON THE NILE
div.p: Sir William Willcocks' new book on the Nile is in the press and will be published at the end of this month. Sir William's leave commenced on Tuesday. He intends spending it on the Nile.

div.head: DEATH OF ARABIC SCHOLAR.
div.p: The Morning Post of last Friday says We regret to announce that Professor H.. Anthony Salmoné, Professor of Arabie at King's College, London, died at his residence, 47, Powis-square, from apoplexy. Of Cretan parentage, he was born in Beyrout in 1860 and educated in the university of that city. Soon after coming to this country he was appointed professor of Arabic at University College, Lon- don, and in 1890 he received the appointment of professor at King's College. In the same year he published an important Arabic-English and English-Arabic Lexicon in two volumes and received a gratifying acknowledgment of his work from the Sultan, who sent him the Order of the Medji-lich of the Third Class in re- cognition of the services he had rendered to Oriental literature. For many years Professor Salmoné, by his addresses and writings, laboured to draw attention to the necessity of encouraging Oriental studies in Great Britain, and he contributed miscellaneous articles to the reviews and newspapers, including the Morning Post. He published in 1896 a book on "The Fall and Resurrection of Turkey," and devised and edited "The Imperial Souvenir," an in- teresting work which was dedicated by special permission to Queen Victoria. It gives a metrical translation of the third verse of the National Anthem in fifty languages spoken in the British Empire.

div.head: THE CAIRO ROADS.
div.p: Since the 3rd October traffic has been stopped on that portion of the Attaba el- Khadra leading from the entrance to the Mohamed Aly-street to the beginning of the Mousky. The shopkeepers have suffered very greatly from this interruption to the traffic. It was officially estimated that the barricade would only last for three days, but it continued from the 3rd October until Monday last, when the work was practically finished. The labourers did their best to prolong the job, and the interests of the merchants and the retail traders in the neighbourhood have suffered very greatly.

div.head: THE EVE OF THE SEASON.
div.p: A HINT TO TRAVELLERS.

We are on the eve of the season, and all the steamers going East are depositing passengers booked for Egypt and the Nile. Some of these are visiting this country for the first time, others are old habitués, among whom are several who are coming to visit the country again after the lapse of many years. The following information will doubtless be of service to many of these.

Society people who come for social pleasures, and who soon tire of Egyptology and sight- seeing, will find one of the new hotels, luxuriously built and equipped to meet all modern requirements (such as the Savoy, Ghezireh Palace, the Continental, or Shepheard's) will afford them a comfortable resting place. But there is another section of the community to be reckoned with and provided for. It is composed of people who are travellers in the true sense; whose object in visiting Cairo is to see all the objects of antique interest-not at a breakneck pace and because they must "get through,"-but in their own way, and who con- template during the winter a long series of lei- surely and reverent ruminations amid the actual scenes made familiar to them in the course of laborious study. Such persons would find the fashionable life and circumstances of the large hotels distinctly distasteful, not to say jarring. But the scientific traveller and studious person is not uncatered for; the Hotel du Nil has always been his headquarters and remains his proper "locale."

It may very probably be news to many who have thought they knew Cairo, that the Hotel du Nil stands 3 metres higher than the Esbekich and the hotels in that quarter. The house is an irregular square in Moorish architecture. Its picturesque character may be taken for granted when it is said that the bedrooms, of which there are 100, open on to verandahs on the ground floor, and on the first floor on to a charming balcony which runs round two of the inner sides of the courtyard. The aspect of the hotel is full South, and its position is sheltered. Moreover, the building has none of the heavy character which is given by much marble, even when it is white in colour.

One has greater warmth, therefore, during the winter at the Hotel du Nil than when lo cated elsewhere in Cairo. One terrace only is marble-paved, and on this the person who wishes a quiet sun-bath may sit and study removed from all the sounds of the town, while) in the middle of it, and commanding a six-acre extent of open ground, is the garden of the Grand Moofty. The observatory tower on the highest terrace commands a most magnificent view. The hole of the city to its farthest circumference (for the Hotel du Nil occupies its mathematical centre) is spread around on all sides. The slender minaret of the Mosque Adi Yehish is the beautiful object close at hand that one notices against the blue sky, in this air,which is certainly as fresh as any inCairo. The Mohamed Aly Mosquestands out well on the city's edge with the Mokattam Hills in the rear, and the Pyramids of Ghizreh and even of Sakarah are comprehended also in the wonderful view. The entrance is on the Khalig, a new, broad roadway opening out from the Mousky; the dining room has windows on three sides, there are two coffee-rooms, and three pleasant salons where refuge and coolness from the midday sunshine and glare of the terrace is acceptable. Breakfast and tea, and in fact any meal at the pleasure of visitors, may be taken in the kiosks in the courtyard, where bananas, date palms, and a banyan afford a green repose for the eyes. The hotel has a dark-room for photographers, a billiard room and bar, bath rooms, and an additional room which is fitted with a very complete douche apparatus. The manage- ment and cooking at the Hotel du Nil are excellent, and the major domo is one of the best-known and most respected men in Cairo, always most successful in making his guests happy and comfortable.

In the early days of the Hotel du Nil, Cairo had no Ismailia, no Tewfikieh, no Doabara quarters. It was Mousky, Mousky, and always Mousky, and for the whole of one's sojourn in Cairo then, as now at the. Nil, whether in the house or out of it, one felt one's self to be really in the East. A foreigner who was com paring his impressions of some European cities the other day was heard to say, "London it is grand, Paris it is magnifique, but Gothenburg- I like it In the same way the verdict of many old habitués of Egypt who come again and again to stay in Cairo is-Shepheard's it is grand, the Savoy it is magnificent, but the Hotel du Nil-I like it.

div.head: FISHERY LAW.
div.p: An Order of the Finance Ministry, issued yesterday, states that as from the 1st January, 1905, the Fishery Law of 1903 shall apply to the Suez Canal. The tariff for boats fishing in the Canal will be that prescribed for Egyptian maritime waters.
The same law will apply to Lake Mariout as from the same date.

div.head: RAILWAY CARRIAGES
div.p: We understand that the Metropolitan Amal- gamated Railway Carriage and Wagon Company of Birmingham have obtained the contract for the supply of carriages for the Egyptian Railway Administration.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman 89. City of Khios mailed yesterday direct for Liverpool with passengers and general cargo including 6.317 bales cotton. The SS Ocean Prince le Antwerp on Wednesday, with passengers and general cargo for Malla and Alexandria.
The SS. Castilian Prince left for Manchester on Tuesday, with general cargo, consisting of 6,560 bales cotton.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: Owing to the absence of a "quorum," the town councillors' meeting did not take place yesterday. As for three months people have been waiting anxiously for the members to return, in order that various affairs in suspense might be settled, this inaction on the part of our civic representatives demands explanation. For three consecutive sittings there has not been a "quorum" and decisions have had to be come to by only a few members at a subsequent meeting. This was the case on the 16th July, 16th October, and it will be the case for the next sitting of the Commission.
We have received the following communication, with a request for its insertion :-
APATHY OF TOWN COUNCIL
26 MEMBERS IN Town
A BURNING QUESTION ON TAPIS.

Yesterday as well as October 12 no quorum, ie, twice within one month. At present I compare our meetings to a friendly social gathering. 4 p.m. is the nominal hour, but those who trouble themselves to be punctual may just wait till a sufficient number to form a quorum saunter in, sometimes this is from 30 to 45 minutes, others after an hour waiting. As yesterday, those who have now wasted their whole afternoon are allowed to go, being total no quorum come again Monday. If the Process were admitted and these sort of things pressed upon the public they might. not occur so often as twice in one month.
Yours obediently,
Gro. B. ALDERON.

div.head: PHARMACY REGULATIONS.
div.p: The following notice has been issued by the Sanitary Administration:

"Pharmacists and all persons, desiring to obtain an authorisation to sell drugs and poisonous substances are informed that the Sanitary Administration holds at their disposal in its offices at Cairo and all the gouvernorats, moudiriehs, and headquarters of districts, model registers and labels which pharmacists are bound to use by Articles 6, 8, 16,17, and 18 of the decree of December 15, 1904, relating to the management of pharmacies and the sale of poisonous drugs.

"Pharmacists are therefore asked to prepare their registers in accordance with those models and forward them to the Sanitary Department numbered and paragraphed in conformity with Art. 6 and 16 of the regulations. For this they are given up to the 31st December.
"The employment of labels of the new model will not be considered necessary till 6 months from the date of publication of the decree.

"Pharmacists who hold licenses to sell poisonous substances according to the decree of 1891 are informed that new licenses must be obtained within ninety days from the publication of the decree, as the licenses which they have previously held become null and void on and after December 21".
The notice also contains details of the examination which must be passed by all vendors of poisonous substances in accordance with the new regulations.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lady Ada Hervey Bathurst and her son will arrive at Mens House Hotel this evening and will stay there for a month before proceeding up the Nile. They arrived at Port Said by the Orient Liner Omrah this morning.
Lady Goldie Taubman is coming to Mens House Hotel next month, and will stay over Christmas.
Judge Vere: Alston, of the Native Court of Appeal, and Mrs. Alston will make a long stay at Mena House Hotel this season, while their new residence at Ghezireh is being built.
Mr. Cotton Fox, who has been a regular visitor to Mena House Hotel for some years past, arrives there on the 15th inst.
Mr. Wright-Henderson, another regular visitor at Mena House Hotel, arrived there to-day.
Sir Augustus and Lady Hemming are going to stay all the winter at Mena.

Among the passengers who disembarked at Port Said on Tuesday afternoon from the P. and O. 8.8. Egypt were Mrs. Mellwraith, Mrs. Wilson, wife of Colonel Wilson, Rifle Brigade, and daughter, Mrs. and Miss Allan Joseph, and Mr. E. H. Harrison, general manager of Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son.
Saba Pasha, the Postmaster-General, left Cairo yesterday evening for Alexandria.
M. Barois is expected to arrive in Cairo next Friday.
Mr. Tottenham will shortly accompany Mr. Dapuis to the Sudan.
The Rev. A. Livingstone left Cairo yesterday to resume his duties in Cyprus.

Professor Dr. E. Schirmer, a very distinguish- ed physician from Marburg, Germany, has arrived at "Al Hayat" for a prolonged stay.. Geheimer Regierungsrat, Dr. Meyer and Fran Meyer are expected at "Al Hayat" tomorrow from Shepheard's Hotel.
Mr. R. S. Patterson, from the Ministry of Public Instruction, has been appointed inspector to the Department of Direct Taxation, Ministry of Finance.
